Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Installing the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway in a clostridium platform organism for enhanced metabolite production

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511660
Papoutsakis, Eleftherios T.

The goal of this project is to engineer the industrial organism Clostridium acetobutylicum to make it capable of utilizing carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and hydrogen, as sole substrates for growth and product formation. This will enable the production of biofuels (e.g. butanol) and other useful chemicals from waste gases in a fermentation system that can be easily scaled for industrial production, and with exceptional efficiencies. From the fundamental point of view, the ability to install this complex, primordial pathway in a different organism constitutes a major advance in synthetic biology that would open new horizons for pathway engineering and synthetic approaches in other industrial microorganisms.

The most efficient pathway for non-photosynthetic chemotrophic carbon utilization is the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway (WLP) employed by acetogens, which are Clostridium organisms that fix enormous quantities of carbon dioxide in the geobiosphere. Comparative genomic analysis of the three sequenced genomes of mesophilic acetogens showed that the WLP genes of all three organisms are concentrated in a highly conserved region in their respective genomes. Based on the published literature and work from the investigator's laboratory, the model acetogen C. ljungdahlii was chosen as the source of most of the WLP genes that will be used to install the WLP in C. acetobutylicum. The plan is to integrate a number of genes into the chromosome and express other genes on two large compatible/co-existing plasmids. Chromosomal integrations will be based on a recently developed technology for double-crossover allelic DNA exchange that enables markerless chromosomal gene deletions and DNA integration. The constructed strains will be assessed for the WLP functionality through in vitro assays, growth experiments and carbon-13 based carbon-fixation assays.

This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to engineer the important industrial organism Clostridium acetobutylicum to make it capable of utilizing carbon dioxide (CO2), carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2), alone and together with sugars in order to improve the yields of metabolites that can be produced using sugar substrates. The impact would be in the development of technologies for production of chemicals and fuels from renewable biomass as well as waste materials (such as syngas, which is a mixture of CO2, CO, H2, that can be generated from waste materials) with exceptionally high yields, fully utilizing all carbon and electron content of the fermentation substrates. The most efficient pathway for non-photosynthetic chemotrophic carbon utilization is the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway (WLP) employed by acetogens, that fix enormous quantities of CO2 in the geobiosphere. Engineering the WLP in the established industrial organism C. acetobutylicum would allow for the conversion of carbohydrates into butanol, acetone, and other metabolites at higher yields than is currently possible, while minimizing CO2 and H2 release. The two important acetogens C. ljungdahlii and C. carboxidivorans were chosen as the source of most of the WLP genes to be used to install the WLP in C. acetobutylicum. The plan was to integrate a number of genes into the chromosome and express other genes on two large compatible/co-existing plasmids. Chromosomal integrations were based on a technology developed in our laboratory for double-crossover allelic DNA exchange that enables markerless chromosomal gene deletions and DNA integration.

Two key enzymes of the WLP used in autotrophic CO2 fixation are the CO dehydrogenase (CODH) and acetyl-CoA synthase (ACS), which form a bifunctional heterotetrameric protein complex.  CODH/ACS can reversibly catalyze CO2 to CO, which is known as the Western branch of the WLP. So far, only a few recombinant CODH/ACS complexes have been expressed in heterologous hosts, none of which demonstrated in vivo functionality in the direction of CO2 reduction. We first demonstrated functional expression of the C. carboxidivorans CODH/ACS complex in C. acetobutylicum, which  was engineered to express CODH alone or together with its partner ACS. Both strains exhibited CO2 reduction and CO oxidation activities. The CODH reactions were interrogated using isotopic labeling, thus verifying that CO was a direct product of CO2 reduction and vice versa. The focus then centered on the functional expression of ACS, which serves to link the two branches of the WLP by catalyzing the formation of acetyl-CoA from the activated methyl group and CO. The Eastern branch forms the activated methyl group from CO2 through formate, and the Western branch forms CO from CO2 . We demonstrated, for the first time in any organism in vivo, the ACS carbonyl-carbon exchange assay, whereby the carbonyl carbon of acetyl-CoA is exchanged with the CO carbon. 

We then expressed the remaining 9 of the presumed 11 C. ljungdahlii core genes coding for enzymes and accessoryproteins of the WLP in C. acetobutylicum. Using 13C-labeled formate, the engineered WLP in C. acetobutylicum showed functionality of the longer Eastern branch, and, as discussed above, of the Western branch, as well. However, the lack of labeling in the acetate pool indicated that the connection between the two branches is not functional. Our interpretation is that some of the genes are not translated at high enough levels into proteins due to post-transcriptional regulation. Our efforts then focused on understanding those aspects of the regulation, and at the same time, to demonstrate the potential of the proposed mixotrophy concept by employing syntrophic co-cultures of two organisms that can accomplish the same goal in a different way. A co-culture between C. acetobutylicum and C. ljungdahlii was chosen to this effect. When cultured together, C. acetobutylicum and C. ljungdahlii form a syntrophic pairing: C. acetobutylicum consumes sugars to initially produce organic acids (acetate and butyrate) and then converts acids to solvents (ethanol, acetone, and butanol) while releasing CO2 and H2 as waste. C. ljungdahlii consumes CO2 and H2 waste to produce additional acetate and ethanol. Thus, the C. acetobutylicum - C. ljungdahlii co-culture is able to convert a higher percentage of sugar substrates into products by consuming gases that would be lost as waste in the conventional acetone-butanol-ethanol (ABE) fermentation of C. acetobutylicum. Interestingly, this syntrophic pair expands the metabolite space of the system: the co-culture was found to produce isopropanol, as well as 2,3-butanediol, none of which is produced by either organism.

This work provides the foundation for engineering a complete and functional WLP in non-native host organisms, and for using syntrophic systems to achieve this goal in a different way. Both approaches are of both fundamental and practical importance in understanding the complex biology of systems that enable efficient utilization of carbon substrates and CO2 fixation for the efficient production of metabolites that maximize resource utilization and minimizes CO2 formation.
